Since this function is exactly the same as shortSubscriberCount, wouldn't it be better to rename shortSubscriberCount  to localizeSubscriberCount? The output of the function is a normal (i.e. with no attributes about size) output, since it can't be considered small when comparing it to the normal output if the normal output does not exist ;-)
Note: removed s from subscribers

In the first commit
Subscriber count is always giving the short count.
We can't get exact number since this YouTube update: https://support.google.com/youtube/thread/6543166
But only short count (B, M, k), so showing full number, eg for 1.9M: 1,900,000, is wrong because the number could be 1,923,490 or 1,897,789…

I sticked to this class «convention»
shortSOMETHINGcount is giving the number with the abbreviation at the end (eg 5000000-> 5M in English US)
localizeSOMETHINGcount is formatting the number (eg 5 million is 5,000,000 in English US but 5 000 000 in French).
So no, this is not the same. 5,000,000 != 5M.
For the s, I followed localizeViewCount (not views count)
Then I don't really understand your comment. Can you re-explain please?
Oh, my fault, I misunderstood something, this is good 😅

This is not a proper value for seconds, it should be using plurals.
To save yet another translation string, maybe we can use a format like "Seconds: %s", or even just the number.

nodes.bodyText:
It's always plural: 5, 10, 15, 20, 25 seconds are all plurals.
I disagree with only number, the result would be 
But 5 what? Seconds, minutes, years? With only number, the user don't know.
And I also disagree with Seconds: %s, to me with Fast forward / rewind seek duration it feels weird, it don't feel like a sentence. If you watch the rest of the menus, and list preferences, the title and entries stays natural, like a sentence.

nodes.bodyText:
I used plural string and included few, many, other as zero, one and two will never be used.
Handled the crash if the string is translated.
And about giving only number or Seconds: %s, I think %s seconds is better.

nodes.bodyText:
Three questions:

Why is getContentLangString giving content country?
Shouldn't we build a localization and return its toString, with both content Language and content country?
Should I use Locale.getDefault().toString() or another one from them (thanks stackoverflow) (I guess it will depend of the two answers above).

Locale.getDefault().getLanguage()       ---> en      
Locale.getDefault().getISO3Language()   ---> eng 
Locale.getDefault().getCountry()        ---> US 
Locale.getDefault().getISO3Country()    ---> USA 
Locale.getDefault().getDisplayCountry() ---> United States 
Locale.getDefault().getDisplayName()    ---> English (United States) 
Locale.getDefault().toString()          ---> en_US
Locale.getDefault().getDisplayLanguage()---> English
Locale.getDefault().toLanguageTag()     ---> en-US

That's a mistake. I already fixed it while working on #1816. However, I didn't push the changes. I'll rebase that branch and push it an Friday or Saturday. There was one thing which kept me from creating a PR though: I added extended debugging which allows one to get the documents which could not be parsed and attend them to the crash report. As a result the crash reports could easily be 1BM and more. Copying and pasting them into the a GitHub app or the browser caused serious lagging on my phone. So it might be better to store the documents in a .zip file and ask the user to upload it. I didn't have time to implement this.
I added a content country field, too. I guess the best thing is to only print the codes which are stored in the app settings.
Should be this. Locale.getDefault().toString()          ---> en_US

nodes.bodyText:
Can you test whether "other" is enough here?
res.getQuantityString(R.plurals.dynamic_seek_duration_description, currentDurationValue) should pick the correct one when "few" or "many" is needed by localization.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -594,4 +592,10 @@
     <string name="choose_instance_prompt">Choose an instance</string>
     <string name="app_language_title">App language</string>
     <string name="systems_language">System default</string>
+    <string name="dynamic_seek_duration_description">%s seconds</string>
+    <plurals name="dynamic_seek_duration_description">
+        <item quantity="few">%s seconds</item>
+        <item quantity="many">%s seconds</item>
+        <item quantity="other">%s seconds</item>
+    </plurals>

nodes.bodyText: Yes, it is enough for English. However, I put all three because I don't know if Weblate will create if I didn't put them for the source string, will it?
